Open-ended childcare responses

Non-parental childcare over time

This week, have you used any non-parental care for your child(ren) under the age of 5?

Response options: Yes, No, Unsure

Rolling average

Challenges

What are the biggest challenges and concerns for you and your family right now?

Race

Income

Mental health

All

1

## Topic 1 Top Words:
##       Highest Prob: incom, financi, offic, reduc, think 
##       FREX: financi, offic, debt, reduc, incom 
##       Lift: finaci, financi, debt, offic, transport 
##       Score: financi, finaci, offic, incom, reduc
## 
##  Topic 1: 
##       Steady income, finding childcare.
##      Reduced income, childcare
##      reduced income, returning my child to daycare
##      We have no childcare, indefinitely, and my job is pushing us to go back into the office.
##      Financial burden of building debt coupled with taking on full time childcare, causing one parent loss of time to work and generate income

2

## Topic 2 Top Words:
##       Highest Prob: get, sick, hard, take, leav 
##       FREX: sick, get, done, hard, groceri 
##       Lift: workdaycar, emerg, impati, sick, breastfeed 
##       Score: get, sick, workdaycar, hard, done
## 
##  Topic 2: 
##       My biggest concern is that I had to use all of my paid time off (sick leave and vacation) when my daughter was born for pregnancy recovery and parental leave. I'm also taking intermittent parental leave one day per week until my daughter turns one. However, in order to do this, I have to have my paid leave banks exhausted all of the time, so I'm very fearful of me or my wife getting sick and being too sick to work and me having no leave. I pay for a short term disability policy but it doesn't take effect until you've missed 2 weeks pay and then it is only 60% income replacement. The policy also only covers my own illness and wouldn't help if my wife was too sick to care for our children.
## 
## The lack of paid parental leave and paid pregnancy disability leave makes our income feel more precarious as a single income household (due to the high cost of childcare where we live, my wife stays home to care for our children) during this public health emergency.
##      Getting mental health and marriage counseling .
## The health of my mother, who does all childcare is troublesome.   She has 2 autoimmune diseases and we are concerned about exposing her
##      My son needs services, possible autism cannot get diagnosed at Kennedy kreiger even on short wait list cannot get in, my daughter wants to be with friends and go to summer camp but waiting for day care to open
##      We recently sent our child back to daycare and it's been great for everyone's mental health; however, there is the stress of her getting sick and bringing it back home. I'm currently 36 weeks pregnant so am concerned about what that would mean if she got sick and passed it on to us.
##      Sharing child care duties while getting important things done for each person, equally

3

## Topic 3 Top Words:
##       Highest Prob: babysitt, expos, babi, test, covid 
##       FREX: babysitt, test, result, expos, medic 
##       Lift: cold, ppd, patient, rest, result 
##       Score: babysitt, cold, test, result, diagnos
## 
##  Topic 3: 
##       My daughter was always on the shy side and sometimes with separation anxiety, a lot of which I attributed to my being a stay at home mom and her always being with me. But since we’ve been completely quarantining for months due to fears of Covid I worry she’ll be socially regressed after this. She’s great with her dad and I but I don’t know how she’ll be with others. Also, it’s been hard to never get a break as a SAHM and hard on our marriage. We used to use a babysitter to go on dates and we miss that.
##      My husband and I being able to have a break from our infant has been difficult because we can't really have a babysitter with the pandemic. We also can't go out to eat or walk around the mall or really go anywhere fun because it's unsafe. It's very isolating to live like this.
##      I'm afraid to seek outside help like a babysitter but I am sleep deprived and was recently diagnosed with PPD.
##      I am unwilling to seek non-parental help (hiring a babysitter) due to fear that it will expose our household to COVID 19.
##      I work in healthcare and I could be exposed to Covid. I'm not sure if my husband would be comfortable with me quarentining I'm there house if I were exposed. We also could really use a break from childcare, which has more to do with my work hours than Covid, but also there aren't many options for social outlets for the 3 year old and he's been desperate for friends.

## 
##  Topic 4: 
##       We had to change daycare due to our previous in home daycare closing. We are very concerned about having to stop working in order to care for our child. They closed due to new state ordered restrictions put in place due to covid. Many childcare places have closed due to this in Maine.
##      If I'm un-furloughed it's a high covid risk position plus my daughter's risk at daycare.
##      There have been positive COVID cases in the daycare but the daycare isn't very concerned and isn't tracing. Daycare has limited hours and is no longer serving food but the cost has stayed the same.
##      I am concerned about finding quality childcare. Many daycare centers are still closed or have limited numbers of children they are taking due to the pandemic. We cannot find our infant a daycare spot and have had to rely on one off baby sitters and family  members to watch him.
##      General safety when attending daycare due to concerns with COVID-19 infection.

##      The loss of the unemployment stipend ($600/week) has pushed us immediately off of a cliff and into free fall.

We purchased a secular homeschool curriculum (because 5 & 3 year olds don’t want to sit in front of an iPad), and check in with their classes a few times a week. We are learning what schooling looks like for us.

##      Scared to send kids back to daycare and scared to go back to the office
##      I have no idea when work is going to call me back and my daycare wants to know when we’re coming back. I don’t want to pay for something I don’t need so the uncertainty is very stressful

12

## Topic 12 Top Words:
##       Highest Prob: week, time, husband, pandem, now 
##       FREX: structur, per, contract, independ, campus 
##       Lift: urgent, averag, handyman, own, preschooldaycar 
##       Score: preschooldaycar, week, structur, watch, potti
## 
##  Topic 12: 
##       My husband owns his own handyman home repair business. It has slowed greatly because people don't have much money for repairs right now and because people don't want people in their house much right now. I am a stay at home mom, but I nanny part time for a family whose mother is a nurse. Her hours have gone down a bit (but she has not been laid off luckily), but that means my hours watching her kids have also decreased, which also hurts our income right now. I am also 34 weeks pregnant and kind of emotional at the moment, paired with my husband's recent behaviors, and our finances being VERY tight this week/month - that has been the point of my recent stress/anxiety. One other thing to point out though, is that is has been very difficult to be in the Texas heat wearing any sort of mask (which I only wear on the rare occasions I am out in public like the grocery store - per our county's mask mandate).
##      My husband owns his own handyman home repair business. With the pandemic, people don't really want visitors in their homes. So his work has dramatically slowed down, lots of big projects cancelled. I bring my daughter with me to nanny a few days a week for a mom who is an urgent care nurse. Her work has thankfully not laid anyone off, but her hours have decreased, which mean I watch her daughter 2 days/wk now instead of previously 3 days/wk, which also means decreased income for us. Besides finances, a lot of my recent stress (in the last week), has been because of potty training my daughter. Even though it's going well, it's a test of patience and very stressful at times. And my husband and I have had 2 major fights in the past week, which is uncommon for us. So my stress is not totally from the pandemic.
##      My husband works for himself and his work has slowed because of COVID and the craziness of the world right now. I nanny part time for an urgent care nurse (and take my daughter with me). She has been able to keep working (despite a lot of other urgent care places laying off employees). So this has been a life saver that I am still able to nanny for her during this time. But her hours have been cut a bit. Thus my hours nannying for her have gone down a little as well (about 2/3 of what they were before). And this week, my daughter has been a little more defiant and clingy and ups/down emotionally because we have just started potty training her. On a usual basis, she is not fussy or defiant at all. But she is testing boundaries these days. Just to see what happens.
##      Loneliness. We are really trying to do our part to help stop the pandemic by minimizing visits with family and friends. This past week, I had a virtual conference for my field (I am a grad student), and my mom and sister came to help with the baby. It made such a world of difference to be able to hug and spend time with someone in addition to my husband. 
## Childcare is the other biggest challenge, insofar as I need to write my dissertation. I get frustrated sometimes that my paycheck is the more reliable of the two of us but my husband's job takes precedent over how we spend our time (he is a journalist so he has to be available at all hours, even though they will only pay him for 35, 40 before the pandemic started). It is really hard to find writing time or interview time with my participants because of this. Before the pandemic, I had planned to hire an in-home nanny two days a week. Now, it's just me and the baby until my husband runs out his 35 hours; then he takes her and I have more research and writing time at the end of the week. So the beginning of the week is always more frustrating than the end regarding our lack of childcare.
##      Youngest child’s behavior (has autism and not having structure of preschool/daycare has been very hard for him).
## quartz_off_screen 
##                 2

##  Topic 13: 
##       We desperately need help from family members, or access to free childcare and socialization for the kids, for multiple reasons: to give us a break, to give us time to find jobs, to help social development for the kids, to help my oldest child feel somewhat normal, etc.
##      No longer having help from family with childcare. 
## The kids understand the virus but are frustrated that they can no longer do many of the things they once enjoyed doing.
##      We are concerned about our 3 year old’s development and education. He was thriving in preschool and now that it’s closed we struggle with providing him the attention and stimulation that he needs. We have a newborn and no outside help with childcare.
##      Being unemployed and not knowing if I'll be employed at the end of the pandemic. If I need to change careers. What to do for childcare if I do need to change careers. My child has asthma.
##      Limiting our interaction and exposure to others when we need medical care, childcare, etc. Elderly family members who want to continue going out on a regular basis.

##  Topic 14: 
##       My biggest concern is about the social development of my daughter. Prior to Covid, we did mom and baby music classes, story times, and Bible studies. For my daughter, she interacted with other adults and toddlers and then suddenly she no longer saw any children and the only adults in her life became me and my husband. She is young, but I wonder if it will affect anything to have gone several months without the opportunity to interact with different adults or other children.
##      As a teacher, my biggest concern is teaching and whether they will let us work from home or force us to teach from our classrooms(remotely).
## I am also seeing more increased social issues for my 5 year old. We’ve seen a behavior change in him especially over the last three weeks.
##      Ensuring interactions with other children when we are not enrolled in daycare or Spanish immersion.
##      I will be returning to work, as maternity leave is ending. My job involves a lot of exposure to the public and young children. I am asthmatic and the 3 year old has a part of a lung missing due to a congenital birth defect. The three year old and 2 month old have to go to daycare, and the older children have to go in person to school so my husband and I can work.
##      Expecting a second child in 6 weeks and fearful of having family visit, watch our oldest.   Would it be safe to go back to daycare?   Who can we really trust with our children as restrictions are loosening and everyone has decided what their own personal definition of "safe" is.  Delivering the baby alone if we can't trust anyone to be there for us safely

##  Topic 15: 
##       Got called for jury duty, trial may be an extended period. Previous childcare arrangement not sufficient.
##      My spouse and I are slowly but surely untangling our finances in preparation for divorce. The kids are handling a two-time arrangement reasonably well. My three year old does not really understand what our divorce means, and he is doing pretty well at adjusting to our new family life. My now six year old (five when I started the survey process) is struggling. She is realizing that her parents won't be getting back together, and that has been heartbreaking. Our nanny also has noticed our six year old acting out a bit more.
##      Childcare. I’m a graduate student employed as a teaching assistant. COVID actually improved my mental well-being because I ended up home with my kids all summer with barely any work to do (I get paid anyway). I had less stress and was actually able to hang out with my kids, whereas before I saw them for like an hour at night before bed. But now that school is starting up, I’m worried about COVID cases exploding in my college town. I worry about what I will do if daycare closes but I still have to teach. And right now finances are tight, my husband hours were cut (unrelatedly to COVID) and my student loans don’t come for another couple weeks.
##      distance learning kindergarten, newly immigrated step child and husband, no work visa for my husband held up by USCIS, no childcare when he can get a job eventually, can't afford childcare, many house repairs and expenses, using up all of my savings, very stressful as a nurse working right now
##      childcare- private nanny costs too much and daycare centers with masks all day would impact language development for baby upon moms return to work.
## 
## School/childcare for older kids- they will be hoke alone and parents will be unable to provide appropriate level of learning support. District is all virtual and both kids have special needs and learning differences with IEPs that the district cannot accommodate. Oldest child developed depression during spring with suicidal ideation, so very concerned about leaving him home alone with noone but his younger sister for company

##  Topic 16: 
##       Our daughter just started preschool again 2 weeks ago after being at home for six months during Pandemic... Unfortunately she was just dismissed because she wasn't behaving properly. They gave her 4 days to adjust and now we have no childcare available. It is extremely frustrating when adults don't understand the children need time to adjust.
##      I was recalled from my job from being on furlough since March. I work in a child care facility and when we closed in March, I was paid by the director until June. I then was furloughed in July and was recalled to my position on 8/29. However, I was only working part time (3 days) when put on furlough and I was recalled to work 5 days. I was unable to do so since I only have child care 3 days a week from my mother. So I had to quit my job. I have been searching for a part time job (working 3 days) since quitting my job. I have been waiting for a decision to be made by unemployment since the beginning of the month to see if I still qualify for unemployment benefits. So essentially, I have had no income for 3 weeks and we have been relying on our savings which are draining. So finances are a challenge and me finding new work is stressful since I can only
## work 3 days due to child care. Additionally, my very active 3.5 year old was pulled from school in March and we are trying to get him enrolled in a local preschool to help him have some routine, peer socialization & time being active outside of the home.
##      Managing infant twins is hard enough to begin with, but I wish we could get a break or have childcare help. Also I am in the middle of changing jobs and we close on a new house this week. So many life changes at once just is stressful - even if they are positive changes, they require a lot of time and attention to detail.
##      My husband is self employed and got no government help. We filed our taxes late and got no stimulus payment. My son started speech therapy for the first time in the middle of this pandemic and it’s been rough. I teach high school and march-may teaching from home was awful when daycares closed.
##      My job may be at risk, with sweeping layoffs coming. Even if I am lucky to maintain a position at my company, it would be smart to begin the search for a new role elsewhere. But looking for a job and potentially starting a new job while I am facing less than ideal childcare issues seems like such a hurdle.

##  Topic 17: 
##       My husband and I are both working from home and splitting childcare. We had intended to hire someone to help with childcare but don't feel confortable doing that in light of the pandemic. We have to split shifts so someone is always caring for the baby, which means we don't see each other much.
##      Knowing the right choice for how much social distancing is enough - especially when it comes to using my mother in law, who is in her 70s for childcare. She was our primary childcare before. Having her back would make an immense difference, but are we putting her at risk? Especially knowing soon my husband may need to travel for work and I may need to go back to a busy, open office environment. In the meantime while we delay that decision, it is just the daily stress of managing video conferences while caring for a busy toddler who is too young for independent play - and then doing the work that can’t be completed during the day overnight.... which means every day is managed with sleep deprivation.
##      We were able to put our mortgage payment on hold in March when my husband was laid off, but the payment will be due in lump sum in August unless we’re able to update the terms of our loan. While we were able to save money, it would be a strain on us financially to pay the lump sum.
## We still do not have a long term child care plan for our son, particularly because none of the options we have outside of our home feel 100% safe so for the most part he is staying with me while I work from home, and my mom is able to help some. 
## It is also getting stressful that the local cases continue to climb and my husband works in a healthcare job where he must be close to others. While they are taking precautions, I’m growing more concerned he may bring home the virus and what that could mean for him, my son, my mom and me. 
## 
##      Baby is scared of everyone except my husband and I, so getting help with child care is nearly impossible. My parents are able to come help off and on as they live a couple hours away, but our daughter screams whenever anyone else tries to come near her / hold her.
##      Like everyone else, childcare. We don’t feel like center-based care will be reliable this year with closures any time there is a diagnosis. We are fortunate enough to be able to afford a nanny, but it is hard to find qualified candidates, especially now that schools are virtual. We have a hospital employee in our home too which makes some people wary of helping us and means we can’t rely on grandparent help like we used to.

##  Topic 18: 
##       affordable childcare. We are paying for a nanny which we can barely afford AND we are trying to negotiate with our daycare provider not to give away our spot because once the pandemic is over spots for daycare are going to be a mad scramble. So we will probably end up paying THEM as well to keep our spot.
##      We would like to put our girls with a good daycare but prices per child are outrageous,  even for part time care.  Also,  not all caregivers apply food, snacks,  diapers,  etc. That would be an additional cost on our end
##      Prices have gotten a lot higher during the pandemic.  The foods we normally buy are sometimes out of stock so we're forced to buy higher priced items.  I had to take my child out of daycare because I couldn't afford the cost anymore.  It's okay for now because I'm working from home but it puts more stress on me to try to get work done and keep her occupied at the same time.
##      child care and food cost. I work in a clinic as a senior medical assistant. I am up at 4am with my children to get them to my mothers house for daycare because i cant not afford to pay for child care for my two kids. I practice daily reiki and meditation. Our daughters love their yoga and my oldest loves her meditation class she takes twice a week. ##      Having a steady income and socially distanced contact with our next door neighbors, whose son is also in my daughter's class at school. The kids have exchanged letters and toys, and we have cooked meals for each other and left them on the doorstep. It's been a nice way to stay connected.
